Finally/Lastly, I want to examine the role of humour in defining a nation’s culture.

believe something Few people believe the claim that the cost of living has not risen since last year.
be believed to be, have, etc. something The vases are believed to be worth over $20 000 each.
be believed + adj. Three sailors are missing, believed drowned.
Do you think (that) they’ll come?
Well, I like it. What do you think?
Police believe (that) the man may be armed.
We all felt (that) we were unlucky to lose.
I reckon (that) I’m going to get that job.
I was under the impression that the work had already been completed.
We have reason to believe that the escaped prisoner may be hiding in this house.
No one seriously believes that this war will happen.
Paul says he's happy, but his mother believes otherwise.

senses.definition: to have the opinion that something is right or true
examples: The party believes (that) education is the most important issue facing the government.
She believes that killing animals for food or fur is completely immoral.
I strongly believe that competition is a good thing.
She truly believes that love can change the world.
Photography is, according to Vidal, the art form of untalented people.
For Vidal, photography is the art form of untalented people.
His view is that photography is not art but merely the mechanical reproduction of images.
Smith takes the view that photography is both an art and a science.
In Brown’s view, photography should be treated as a legitimate art in its own right.
James is of the opinion that a good painter can always be a good photographer if they so decide.
Emerson believed that a photograph should only reflect what the human eye can see.
In my opinion, everyone should have some understanding of science.
Everyone should, in my opinion, have some understanding of science.
It seems to me that many people in this country have a poor understanding of science.
This is, in my view, the result of a failure of the scientific community to get its message across.
Another reason why so many people have such a poor understanding of science is, I believe, the lack of adequate funding for science in schools.
Smith argues that science is separate from culture. My own view is that science belongs with literature, art, philosophy and religion as an integral part of our culture.
In this writer’s opinion, the more the public know about science, the less they will fear and distrust it.
I personally believe that it's important.
I've long believed that a good reputation is the most valuable asset you can have in business.
I believe that we have a responsibility towards the less fortunate in society.

senses.definition: used to say that you are surprised or annoyed at something
examples: believe (that)… She couldn’t believe (that) it was all happening again.
I don't believe I'm doing this!
believe how, what, etc… I can't believe how much better I feel.
I couldn't believe what I was hearing.

senses.definition: to have a religious faith
examples: The god appears only to those who believe.

senses.definition: used to introduce information that is true but that may surprise people
examples: Believe it or not, he asked me to marry him!

senses.definition: used to emphasize that you strongly believe what you are saying
examples: You haven't heard the last of this, believe you me!

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that something is definitely not true
examples: ‘She wouldn’t do a thing like that.’ ‘Don’t you believe it!’

senses.definition: to make somebody believe/understand something
examples: I was given to understand that she had resigned.

senses.definition: used to say that you are surprised or annoyed about something
examples: I don't believe it! What are you doing here?

senses.definition: used to say that you think somebody is stupid if they believe that something is true
examples: ‘He promised not to do it again.’ ‘Sure, and if you believe that, you’ll believe anything.’

senses.definition: to pretend that something is true
to be very surprised at something you hear/see
examples: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody will have to believe that something is true when they see it, although they do not think it is true now
used to show that you are surprised and annoyed about something
examples: And, would you believe, they didn't even apologize!

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that something is definitely true
examples: ‘He’s not a bad player, is he?’ ‘You’d better believe it!’

senses.definition: a hollow metal object, often like a cup in shape, that makes a ringing sound when hit by a small piece of metal inside it; the sound that it makes
examples: A peal of church bells rang out in the distance.
a bicycle bell
His voice came down the line as clear as a bell.
the bell of a trumpet (= the part at the end like a bell in shape)
The church bells rang out.
a bell-shaped flower
Off in the distance a bell tolled two in the morning.
a bell tower
wedding bells
The dancers wore bells on their ankles.
The bells on the harness tinkled softly.
The church bells tolled for Evensong.
the faint chime of bells
Their friends could already hear wedding bells (= were sure they would get married).

senses.definition: an electrical device which makes a ringing sound when a button on it is pushed; the sound that it makes, used as a signal or a warning
examples: Ring the bell to see if they're in.
The bell's ringing!
The bell went for the end of the lesson.
An alarm bell went off.
(figurative) Warning bells started ringing in her head as she sensed that something was wrong.
(figurative) This decision is going to sound a warning bell to other couples.
Saved by the bell! (= a bell that signals the end of something) I thought I'd have to sit here listening to you two argue forever.

senses.definition: if you say that alarm bells are ringing, you mean that people are starting to feel worried and to suspect that something is wrong
examples: The government’s proposal has set alarm bells ringing for people on low incomes.

senses.definition: to call somebody by phone
used to show that you do not believe what somebody has just said
to sound familiar to you, as though you have heard it before
examples: His name rings a bell but I can't think where we met.

senses.definition: in perfect condition
examples: The doctor said I was as sound as a bell.

senses.definition: to be in the right or suitable place
examples: Where do these plates belong (= where are they kept)?
Are you sure these documents belong together?
Several of the points you raise do not belong in this discussion.
A person like that does not belong in teaching.

senses.definition: to feel comfortable and happy in a particular situation or with a particular group of people
examples: I don't feel as if I belong here.

senses.definition: at or to a lower level, position or place
examples: They live on the floor below.
I could still see the airport buildings far below.
See below (= at the bottom of the page) for references.
The passengers who felt seasick stayed below (= on a lower deck).

senses.definition: at a lower rank
examples: This ruling applies to the ranks of Inspector and below.

senses.definition: lower than zero
examples: The thermometer had dropped to a record 40 below (= −40 degrees).

senses.definition: at or to a lower level or position than somebody/something
examples: He dived below the surface of the water.
Please do not write below this line.
Skirts will be worn below (= long enough to cover) the knee.

senses.definition: of a lower amount or standard than somebody/something
examples: The temperatures remained below freezing all day.
Her work was well below average for the class.

senses.definition: of a lower rank or of less importance than somebody/something
examples: A police sergeant is below an inspector.

senses.definition: a long narrow piece of leather, cloth, etc. that you wear around the middle part of your body
examples: to do up/fasten/tighten a belt
a belt buckle
a studded leather belt
Around his waist he wore a belt.

senses.definition: a continuous band of material that moves round and is used to carry things along or to drive a machine
a narrow area or an area around the edge of something that has particular characteristics
examples: the country’s corn/industrial belt
We live in the commuter belt.
a narrow belt of trees
a belt of rain moving across the country
Towns in the country's industrial belt were particularly affected by the recession.

senses.definition: an act of hitting something/somebody hard
examples: She gave the ball a terrific belt.

senses.definition: unfair or cruel
examples: That was distinctly below the belt!

senses.definition: taking more actions than are really necessary to make sure that something succeeds or works as it should
examples: a belt-and-braces policy

senses.definition: to have already achieved or obtained something
examples: She already has a couple of good wins under her belt.

senses.definition: to spend less money because there is less available
examples: With price increases on most goods, everyone is having to tighten their belt.
There is a need for further belt-tightening.

senses.definition: a curve or turn, especially in a road or river
examples: a sharp bend in the road
You took that bend very fast!
He lost control on a bend and crashed into a tree.
As the driver came round the bend, she saw the lorry.
He had a winning lead off the final bend.
I inched the car into the bend.
Slow down on the tight bends.
The car vanished around a bend.
a series of dangerous bends
a wide bend in the river
mountain roads with steep gradients and blind bends (= that you cannot see around)

senses.definition: severe pain and difficulty in breathing experienced by a diver who comes back to the surface of the water too quickly
crazy
examples: I would go round the bend if I had your job.
The kids have been driving me round the bend today (= annoying me very much).

senses.definition: to lean, or make something lean, in a particular direction
examples: He bent and kissed her.
The doctor told me to avoid bending and stretching.
+ adv./prep. fields of poppies bending in the wind
She suddenly bent over, clutching her stomach.
She bent over him to reach her book.
He bent forward to pick up the package.
Slowly bend from the waist and bring your head down to your knees.
Keep your feet apart, and bend at the waist
bend something He bent his head and kissed her.
bend something + adv./prep. She bent her head towards him.
She was bent over her desk writing a letter.
He came closer and bent towards her.
I bent down and tied my shoelace.
I had to bend double to get under the table.
Sarah bent close to him.

senses.definition: if you bend your arm, leg, etc. or if it bends, you move it so that it is no longer straight
examples: bend something Bend your knees, keeping your back straight.
Lie flat and let your knees bend.

senses.definition: to force something that was straight into an angle or a curve
examples: Mark the pipe where you want to bend it.
The knives were bent out of shape.
He bent the wire into the shape of a square.

senses.definition: to change direction to form a curve or an angle; to make something change direction in this way
examples: The road bent sharply to the right.
bend something Glass and water both bend light.

senses.definition: to talk to somebody a lot about something, especially about a problem that you have
to think very hard about or put a lot of effort into one particular thing
examples: She bent her mind to the problem of escape.

senses.definition: to make a great effort, especially in order to be helpful or fair
examples: I've bent over backwards to help him.

senses.definition: to change the rules to suit a particular person or situation
examples: Couldn't they just bend the rules and let us in without a ticket?

senses.definition: to say something that is not completely true
examples: I wasn’t exactly lying when I said I hadn’t seen her—I was just bending the truth a little.

senses.definition: if you ask for something on bended knee(s), you ask for it in a very anxious and/or humble way (= showing you think you are less important than the person you are asking)
examples: I’d go down on bended knee if I thought she’d change her mind.

senses.definition: an advantage that something gives you; a helpful and useful effect that something has
examples: Freedom of information brings great benefits.
health/economic/tax benefits
the benefits of modern medicine
I've had the benefit of a good education.
It was good to see her finally reaping the benefits (= enjoying the results) of all her hard work.
The industry will be one of the first to enjoy the benefits of the recovery.
The company derived substantial benefit from the deal.
benefit of doing something He couldn't see the benefit of arguing any longer.
be of benefit to somebody/something The new regulations will be of benefit to everyone concerned.
to somebody's benefit It will be to your benefit to arrive early.
benefit for somebody/something The project will have major benefits for the local community.
With the benefit of hindsight (= knowing what we have learnt since), we would do things differently.
without the benefit of something Nobody should be sent to prison without the benefit of legal advice.
For maximum benefit, take the tablets before meals.
The different environmental groups could work together to their mutual benefit.
They somehow manage to work without the benefit of modern technology.
I can see the benefits that such games give children.
If you want to maximize the benefits of blueberries, eat them raw.
The benefits easily outweigh the cost.
The method has many additional benefits.
The new factory will bring considerable benefits to the area.
This deal will offer major benefits to industrialists and investors.
Weigh the benefits of hiring help before hiring new employees.
What are the benefits to investors?
Consumers choose organic meat for a number of reasons, including perceived health benefits.
a marketing campaign which promotes the cosmetic benefits of vitamin E

senses.definition: money provided by the government to people who need financial help because they are unemployed, ill, etc.
examples: You may be eligible to receive benefits.
The number of people claiming unemployment benefit fell last month.
on benefits The aim is to help people who are on benefits (= receiving benefits) to find jobs.
He's on social security benefit.
She is worried that if she takes on a job she will lose her benefits.
One way to cut spending is to move from universal benefits—those paid to everyone regardless of need—to means-tested ones.
Benefit is paid monthly.

senses.definition: an advantage that you get from a company in addition to the money that you earn
examples: Private health insurance is offered as part of the employees' benefits package.
These benefits will now be extended to agency workers.

senses.definition: money from an insurance company
examples: The insurance plan will provide substantial cash benefits to your family in case of your death.

senses.definition: an event such as a performance, a dinner, etc., organized in order to raise money for a particular person or charity
examples: a benefit match/concert
The proceeds from the benefit will go directly to the refugee camps.

senses.definition: especially in order to help or be useful to somebody
examples: I have attached some lecture notes for the benefit of those people who were absent last week.
Don't go to any trouble for my benefit!

senses.definition: to accept that somebody has told the truth or behaved well because you cannot prove that they have not
examples: She may have been lying, but I felt I had to give her the benefit of the doubt.

senses.definition: to be useful to somebody or improve their life in some way
examples: We should spend the money on something that will benefit everyone.
The new tax laws will clearly benefit those on low wages.
The project will benefit the local community as a whole.

senses.definition: to be in a better position because of something
examples: We all benefit when our young people realize their potential.
benefit from something Who exactly stands to benefit from these changes?
benefit by doing something Most crime victims benefit greatly by talking about their experiences.
We benefited directly from the reorganization.
We both benefited financially from the arrangement.

senses.definition: not straight
examples: a piece of bent wire
Do this exercise with your knees bent (= not with your legs straight).
The lamp post got bent in the crash.
Lock your elbows in a slightly bent position.

senses.definition: not able to stand up straight, usually as a result of being old or ill
examples: a small bent old woman
He was bent double with laughter.

senses.definition: dishonest
determined to do something (usually something bad)
examples: She seems bent on making life difficult for me.
to be bent on destruction/revenge
He's your typical supervillain, bent on world domination.

senses.definition: to become angry, anxious or upset
examples: Don't get bent out of shape about it. It was just a mistake!

senses.definition: of the most excellent type or quality
examples: That's the best movie I've ever seen!
He wrote his best songs before he was 25.
She was one of the best tennis players of her generation.
Is that your best suit?
They've been best friends (= closest friends) since they were children.
the company’s best-ever results
We want the kids to have the best possible education.
This is by far the best restaurant in the town.
We aim to give our guests the very best attention.
Who in the class is best at history?

senses.definition: giving most pleasure; happiest
examples: Those were the best years of my life.

senses.definition: most suitable or appropriate
examples: What's the best way to cook steak?
Which is the best tool for this job?
The best thing to do would be to apologize.
It's best if you go now.
I'm not in the best position to advise you.
Owen judged it best to make no reply.

senses.definition: most; to the greatest extent
examples: Which one do you like best?
Well-drained soil suits the plant best.
her best-known poem

senses.definition: in the most excellent way; to the highest standard
examples: He works best in the mornings.
Britain’s best-dressed woman
The beaches are beautiful, but, best of all, there are very few tourists.

senses.definition: in the most suitable or appropriate way
examples: Painting is best done in daylight.
Do as you think best (= what you think is the most suitable thing to do).

senses.definition: not perfectly but as well as you are able
examples: We'll manage as best we can.

senses.definition: to be famous or known for a particular thing that you have done in the past
examples: He is best remembered as the man who brought jazz to England.
She is best remembered for her first book, ‘In the Ditch’.

senses.definition: the most excellent thing or person
examples: We all want the best for our children.
They only buy the best.
They're all good players, but she's the best of all.
We're the best of friends (= very close friends).

senses.definition: the highest standard that somebody/something can reach
examples: She always brings out the best in people.
The town looks its best (= is most attractive) in the spring.
Don't worry about the exam—just do your best.
The roses are past their best now.
I don't really feel at my best today.

senses.definition: something that is as close as possible to what you need or want
examples: Fifty pounds is the best I can offer you.
The best we can hope for in the game is a draw.

senses.definition: the highest standard that a particular person has reached, especially in a sport
examples: a lifetime best of 12.0 seconds

senses.definition: used when you are saying goodbye to somebody or ending a letter, to give somebody your good wishes
used for saying what is the best opinion you can have of somebody/something, or the best thing that can happen, when the situation is bad
examples: Their response to the proposal was, at best, cool.
We can't arrive before Friday at best.

senses.definition: used to say that although something appears bad or unpleasant now, it will be good in the end
examples: I don't want you to leave, but perhaps it's for the best.

senses.definition: a person or thing that is a little better than the rest of a group, although none are very good
the best out of a group of people or things
used to wish somebody success with something
examples: The best of luck with your exams.
Good luck! I hope it goes well.
(ironic) ‘I'm going to try giving up social media for a year.’ ‘Good luck with that (= I don't think you will succeed).’

senses.definition: up to three, five, etc. games played to decide who wins, the winner being the person who wins most of them
the very best
examples: We make sure our clients get the best that money can buy.

senses.definition: to do or say something in order to achieve a good result or to help somebody
examples: I just don't know what to do for the best.
I'm sorry if my advice offended you—I meant it for the best.

senses.definition: to gain more advantage from something than somebody else
examples: I thought you had the best of that discussion.

senses.definition: to hope that something will happen successfully, especially where it seems likely that it will not
examples: I’m just going to answer all the questions I can and hope for the best.

senses.definition: to accept a bad or difficult situation and do as well as you can
your best clothes
examples: I put on my Sunday best for the occasion.

senses.definition: as far as you know
examples: He never made a will, to the best of my knowledge.

senses.definition: as well as anyone
examples: He'll be out there, dancing with the best of them.

senses.definition: an arrangement to risk money, etc. on the result of a particular event; the money that you risk in this way
examples: to win/lose a bet
I was tempted to place a large bet.
bet on something We've got a bet on who's going to arrive first.
He had a bet on the horses.
They all put a bet on the race.
I hear you're taking bets on whether she'll marry him.
I did it for a bet (= because somebody had agreed to pay me money if I did).
‘Liverpool are bound to win.’ ‘Do you want a bet?’ (= I disagree with you, I don't think they will.)
I made a bet with a friend.
I wish I hadn't agreed to that stupid bet.
We are now taking bets on the election result.

senses.definition: an opinion about what is likely to happen or to have happened
examples: My bet is that they've been held up in traffic.

senses.definition: used to say that if a particular event happens then your current prediction, agreement, etc. will no longer apply
examples: We expect shares to rise unless the economy slows down again, in which case all bets are off.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody what is the best action for them to take to get the result they want
examples: If you want to get around London fast, the Underground is your best bet.

senses.definition: something that is likely to happen, to succeed or to be suitable
examples: He's a good bet to earn a spot on the US team.
Clothes are a safe bet as a present for a teenager.
The movie looks like a sure bet for Best Film.

senses.definition: to reduce the risk of losing or making a mistake by supporting more than one side in a competition, an argument, etc., or by having several choices available to you
examples: She hedged her bets by applying for various other jobs as well.

senses.definition: to risk money on a race or an event by trying to predict the result
examples: You have to be over 16 to bet.
bet on/against somebody/something doing something I wouldn't bet on them winning the next election.
Not many people are betting against France retaining their title.
bet on/against something He likes betting on horses and watching table tennis.
bet something on something He bet $2 000 on the final score of the game.
bet something You shouldn't praise a gambler for betting his life savings if he wins.
bet somebody something (that) She bet me £20 (that) I wouldn't do it.
bet somebody (that) I bet her (that) the Democrats would not win.
bet something (that) He bet ten dollars (that) he could write a complete story in just six words.

senses.definition: used to say that you are almost certain that something is true or that something will happen
examples: bet (that)… I bet (that) we’re too late.
You can bet (that) the moment I sit down, the baby will wake up.
I'm willing to bet (that) the analysts will be wrong.
bet somebody (that)… I’ll bet you (that) he knows all about it.

senses.definition: to risk everything you have on an investment, a bet, etc.
examples: The company bet the farm on the new marketing model, only to find that it wasn’t successful.

senses.definition: used to show that you can understand what somebody is feeling, describing, etc.
examples: ‘I nearly died when he told me.’ ‘I bet!’

senses.definition: used to tell somebody that you do not believe what they have just said
examples: ‘I'm going to tell her what I think of her.’ ‘Yeah, I bet!’

senses.definition: used to say that you do not think that something is very likely
examples: ‘She'll soon get used to the idea.’ ‘I wouldn't bet on it.’

senses.definition: used instead of ‘yes’ to emphasize that somebody has guessed something correctly or made a good suggestion
examples: ‘Are you nervous?’ ‘You bet!’

senses.definition: used to say that you are certain that something will happen
examples: You can bet your bottom dollar that he'll be late.

senses.definition: of a higher standard or less poor quality; not as bad as something else
examples: We're hoping for better weather tomorrow.
Her work is getting better and better.
He is in a much better mood than usual.
The meal couldn't have been better.
There's nothing better than a long soak in a hot bath.
If you can only exercise once a week, that's better than nothing (= better than taking no exercise at all).
I might not be a brilliant cook, but that meal's a darn sight better than anything you could do.
I think he's a hundred times better as a teacher than Mr White.

senses.definition: more suitable or appropriate
examples: Can you think of a better word than ‘nice’?
It would be better for him to talk to his parents about his problems.
You'd be better going by bus.
I thought it better to tackle him outside of business hours.
We must make our inner cities better to live and work in.

senses.definition: more able; showing more skill
examples: She's far better at science than her brother.

senses.definition: less ill or unhappy
examples: She's a lot better today.
His leg was getting better.
You'll feel all the better for a good night's sleep.

senses.definition: fully recovered after an illness; in good health again
examples: Don't go back to work until you are better.
Don't worry. The doctor will soon make you better.
I hope you get better soon.

senses.definition: most of something, especially a period of time; more than half of something
examples: He drank the best part of a bottle of Scotch waiting for her to get home.
The journey took her the better part of an hour.

senses.definition: used to say that something should be as big, small, etc. as possible
examples: I love giving parties, the bigger the better.

senses.definition: you should avoid danger and not take unnecessary risks
almost or just the same as; almost or just as bad as
examples: The path was no better than a sheep track.
Charles VII was a bad king and Charles VIII was no better.

senses.definition: it is better to stop something bad from happening rather than try to deal with the problems after it has happened
examples: Prevention is better than cure, so start looking after your heart now.
Prevention is better than cure, so start taking care of yourself.

senses.definition: used to give support to somebody who has been upset and is trying to become calmer
examples: Dry your eyes now. That's better.

senses.definition: used to praise somebody who has made an effort to improve
examples: That's much better—you played the right notes this time.

senses.definition: used to say that two people can achieve more than one person working alone
in a more excellent or pleasant way; not as badly
examples: She sings much better than I do.
Sound travels better in water than in air.
People are better educated now.

senses.definition: more; to a greater degree
examples: You'll like her when you know her better.
A cup of tea? There's nothing I'd like better!
Fit people are better able to cope with stress.
Researchers are hoping to better understand the role of this protein in human disease.

senses.definition: used to suggest that something would be a suitable or appropriate thing to do
examples: The money could be better spent on more urgent cases.
Some things are better left unsaid.
You'd do better to tell her everything before she finds out from someone else.

senses.definition: to have more money
examples: Families will be better off under the new law.
Her promotion means she's $100 a week better off.

senses.definition: used to say that somebody is/would be happier or more satisfied because they are/if they were in a particular position or doing a particular thing
examples: She's better off without him.
The weather was so bad we'd have been better off staying at home.

senses.definition: used to say that while one thing is good, another thing is even better
examples: You can see and, better yet, hear the effects of these changes on their website.
I wanted to make my parents proud by becoming a lawyer or, better yet, a doctor.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody what you think they should do
examples: You'd better go to the doctor about your cough.
We'd better leave now or we'll miss the bus.
You'd better not do that again.
‘I'll give you back the money tomorrow.’ ‘You'd better!’ (= as a threat)
If you think it is going to be easy, you'd best think again.
You should take the baby to the doctor’s.
You ought to be ashamed of yourself!
Should we call the doctor?
We’d better hurry or we’ll miss the train.
She should have asked for some help.
You ought to have been more careful.
You shouldn’t drive so fast.
I’m sorry, I shouldn’t have lost my temper.

senses.definition: something that is better
examples: the better of the two books
I expected better of him (= I thought he would have behaved better).

senses.definition: people who are more intelligent or more important than you
a person, thing, situation, etc. that is better/worse than the previous or present one
examples: Voters see the new leader as a change for the better.
I reckon we've all made a big change for the better.
His family had detected a change for the worse in his behaviour.

senses.definition: people who are older and wiser than you and that you should respect
used to say that something cannot be changed, whether the result is good or bad
to defeat somebody/something or gain an advantage
examples: No one can get the better of her in an argument.
She always gets the better of an argument.
His curiosity got the better of him (= he didn't intend to ask questions, but he wanted to know so badly that he did).

senses.definition: used to say that something is even better/worse
examples: We don't actually need it on Tuesday, but if it arrives by then, so much the better.
If hurricanes become more powerful, as current research suggests, so much the worse.

senses.definition: to have a higher opinion of somebody
examples: She has behaved appallingly—I must say I thought better of her.

senses.definition: in the space or period of time separating two or more points, objects, etc. or two dates, events, etc.
examples: The house was near a park but there was a road in between.
I see her most weekends but not very often in between.

senses.definition: in a middle position; neither one thing nor the other
examples: He found himself placed betwixt and between in the debate, agreeing with parts of each side’s arguments.

senses.definition: in or into the space separating two or more points, objects, people, etc.
examples: Q comes between P and R in the English alphabet.
I sat down between Jo and Diana.
Switzerland lies between France, Germany, Austria and Italy.

bother with/about something It's not worth bothering with (= using) an umbrella—the car's just outside.

bother to do something He didn't even bother to let me know he was coming.

senses.definition: to annoy, worry or upset somebody; to cause somebody trouble or pain

bother somebody with something I don't want to bother her with my problems at the moment.

senses.definition: to interrupt somebody; to talk to somebody when they do not want to talk to you

to not spend time/effort on something, because it is not important or you are not interested in it

senses.definition: having stopped operating as a business because there is no more money or work available
examples: The new regulations will put many small businesses out of business.
Some travel companies will probably go out of business this summer.
The company went out of business during the recession.

senses.definition: to look for customers, passengers, etc. in order to do business
examples: taxis plying for hire outside the theatre

senses.definition: a man who works in business, especially at a high level
examples: a group of visiting Italian politicians and businessmen

senses.definition: a man who shows skill in business and financial matters
examples: a successful/wealthy businessman
For many years he was a successful businessman, running his own small business.
I should have got a better price for the car, but I'm not much of a businessman.
He has a reputation as a shrewd businessman.

senses.definition: having a lot to do; perhaps not free to do something else because you are working on something
examples: Are you busy tonight?
I'm afraid the doctor is busy at the moment. Can he call you back?
The principal is a very busy woman.
I'll be too busy to come to the meeting.
She was always too busy to listen.
I've got enough work to keep you busy.

senses.definition: giving all your attention and effort to a particular activity
examples: busy doing something James is busy practising for the school concert.
They were busy enjoying themselves at the party.
busy with something/somebody Kate's busy with her homework.
Let's get busy with the clearing up.

senses.definition: full of work and activity
examples: Have you had a busy day?
I have a very busy schedule.
This is one of the busiest times of the year for the department.
We've got a busy week ahead of us.
We had a busy weekend lined up.
a very busy life
Things are getting really busy now.

senses.definition: full of people, activity, vehicles, etc.
examples: a busy road/street
The place gets very busy at lunchtimes.
We have to cross a busy main road to get to school.
Victoria is one of London's busiest stations.

senses.definition: being used
examples: The line is busy—I'll try again later.
the busy signal

senses.definition: too full of small details
examples: This wallpaper is too busy for the bedroom.

senses.definition: very busy
to find enough things to do
examples: Since she retired she's kept herself very busy.
She needed to keep busy.

senses.definition: used to introduce a word or phrase that contrasts with what was said before
examples: I got it wrong. It wasn't the red one but the blue one.
His mother won't be there, but his father might.
It isn't that he lied exactly, but he does tend to exaggerate.

senses.definition: however; despite this
examples: I'd asked everybody but only two people came.
By the end of the day we were tired but happy.
While the film is undoubtedly too long, it is nevertheless an intriguing piece of cinema.
It can be argued that the movie is too long. It is nonetheless an intriguing piece of cinema.
The film is undoubtedly too long. Still, it is an intriguing piece of cinema.
Of course, huge chunks of the book have been sacrificed in order to make a two-hour movie, but it is nevertheless a successful piece of storytelling.
Critics are wrong to argue that the film’s plot is too complicated. Certainly there are a couple of major twists, but audiences will have no difficulty following them.
It is true that you cannot make a good movie without a good script, but it is equally true that a talented director can make a good script into an excellent film.
It remains to be seen whether these two movies herald a new era of westerns, but there is no doubt that they represent welcome additions to the genre.

senses.definition: used when you are saying sorry about something
examples: I'm sorry but I can't stay any longer.

senses.definition: used to introduce a statement that shows that you are surprised or annoyed, or that you disagree
examples: But that's not possible!
‘Here's the money I owe you.’ ‘But that's not right—it was only £10.’

senses.definition: except
examples: I had no choice but to sign the contract.

senses.definition: used before repeating a word in order to emphasize it
examples: Nothing, but nothing would make him change his mind.

senses.definition: used to emphasize that something is always true
examples: She never passed her old home but she thought of the happy years she had spent there (= she always thought of them).

senses.definition: if it were not for
examples: He would have played but for a knee injury.

senses.definition: except for
examples: The square was empty but for a couple of cabs.

senses.definition: however; on the other hand
examples: He might agree. But then again he might have a completely different opinion.

senses.definition: used before a statement that explains or gives a reason for what has just been said
examples: She speaks very good Italian. But then she did live in Rome for a year (= so it's not surprising).

senses.definition: used to show that everything else is impossible except the thing that you are saying
examples: What could he do but forgive her? (= that was the only thing possible)

senses.definition: except; apart from
examples: We've had nothing but trouble with this car.
The problem is anything but easy.
Who but Rosa could think of something like that?
Everyone was there but him.
I came last but one in the race (= I wasn't last but next to last).
Take the first turning but one (= not the first one but the one after it).

senses.definition: a soft yellow food made from cream, used in cooking and for spreading on bread
examples: Fry the onions in butter.
a pat/knob/tablespoon of butter
(North American English) a stick (= small pack) of butter
Melt the butter in a small pan, add the flour and stir well.
Do you want butter or margarine on your toast?
Cream the butter and icing sugar together until light and fluffy.
He put a large knob of butter on the potatoes.
She spread butter on the roll.
Put some butter on the crackers, please.
Rub the butter into the flour.
The butter melted in the heat.
This butter doesn't spread very well.
You can make frosting out of half a stick of butter and two cups of powdered sugar.
courgettes sautéed in butter

senses.definition: used to say that somebody seems to be innocent, kind, etc. when they are not really
easily; without meeting any difficulty
a small round piece of metal, plastic, etc. that is sewn onto a piece of clothing and used for fastening two parts together
examples: (British English) to do up/undo your buttons
(North American English) to button/unbutton your buttons
to sew on a button
shirt buttons
a row of gilt buttons
One of the buttons on his jacket was missing.
My coat has lost a button.
The top button of his shirt was undone.
There was a button missing from his shirt.
His fingers fumbled to do up/​button the small buttons on his shirt.
I need to sew this button back on.

senses.definition: a small part of a machine that you press to make it work
examples: the start/stop/pause button
Adam pressed a button and waited for the lift.
Choose ‘printer’ from the menu and click with the right mouse button.
She pushed a button on the control panel.
I hit the play button on the remote.
The windows slide down at the touch of a button.
With a push of a button, I can print out everything I need.
She hit the alarm button as fast as she could.
The remote control allows you to change channel at the touch of a button.

senses.definition: a small area on a computer screen that you click on to make it do something
examples: Click on the back button to go back to the previous screen.
Click the ‘Finish’ button in the top right-hand corner of the screen.
I hit the ‘Reply’ button in the mail toolbar.

senses.definition: a badge, especially one with a message printed on it
examples: He wore a button saying ‘Life begins at 40!’
She wore a ‘Vote Yes’ lapel button.
The candidates all distributed campaign buttons and bumper stickers.
They all wore buttons saying ‘Stop the war’.
He carries around an old backpack with peace buttons on it.

senses.definition: intelligent and quick to understand
at exactly the right time or at the exact time mentioned
examples: We arrived at 4 o'clock on the button.

senses.definition: exactly right
examples: You're on the button there!

senses.definition: to do exactly the right things to please somebody
examples: a new satirical comedy show that pushes all the right buttons

senses.definition: to make somebody react in either a positive or a negative way
examples: I've known him for years, but I still don't know what pushes his buttons.

senses.definition: to obtain something by paying money for it
examples: buy (something) Where did you buy that dress?
She had no money to buy a ticket.
They can't afford to buy school books.
If you're thinking of getting a new car, now is a good time to buy.
buy something from somebody/something I bought it from a friend for £10.
buy something off somebody/something (informal) She bought it off eBay for $50.
buy somebody something Mum bought me a new coat.
buy something for somebody Mum bought a new coat for me.
buy something + adv./prep. I bought my car second-hand.
They buy all their groceries in bulk .
+ adv./prep. It's generally cheaper if you buy online.
They make their money by buying cheap and selling dear.
Some people buy all their groceries online.
I think he was motivated by his mother.
Don't let the opportunity pass you by.
Bye! See you later.
They bought a car for their daughter.
I bought it for $25.
She bought some books from a friend.
I can't afford to buy a new car.
Old bicycles can be bought quite cheaply.
She makes her living buying and selling antiques.
Was the produce imported or bought locally?
We can afford to buy enough paint to do the whole house.
Young people are very comfortable buying online.

senses.definition: to be enough to pay for something
examples: He gave his children the best education that money can buy.
Five pounds doesn't buy much nowadays.
There are some things money can't buy.

senses.definition: to persuade somebody to do something dishonest in return for money
examples: He can't be bought (= he's too honest to accept money in this way).

senses.definition: to obtain something by losing something else of great value
examples: Her fame was bought at the expense of her marriage.

senses.definition: to believe that something is true, especially something that is not very likely
examples: You could say you were ill but I don't think they'd buy it (= accept the explanation).

senses.definition: the very best
examples: We make sure our clients get the best that money can buy.

senses.definition: to have been killed, especially in an accident or a war
examples: Joe finally bought it in a plane crash in Tunisia.

senses.definition: to get back a country's assets, such as land or property, after they have been owned by another country
examples: The prime minister revealed his plan to buy back the farm from foreign ownership.

senses.definition: to die
to do something in order to delay an event, a decision, etc.
examples: The negotiators kept the gunman talking to buy time for the hostages.

senses.definition: if you buy a pig in a poke, you buy something without seeing it or knowing if it is good enough
examples: Buying online can mean buying a pig in a poke.

senses.definition: to sell somebody something/to buy something that has no value or is worth much less than the price paid
past
examples: Just drive by. Don't stop.
He hurried by without speaking to me.
Excuse me, I can't get by.
Time goes by so quickly.
Some people buy all their groceries online.
I think he was motivated by his mother.
Don't let the opportunity pass you by.
Bye! See you later.

senses.definition: used to say that something is saved so that it can be used in the future
examples: I've put some money by for college fees.

senses.definition: in order to visit somebody for a short time
examples: I'll come by this evening and pick up the books.

senses.definition: before long; soon
examples: By and by she met an old man with a beard.

senses.definition: used when you are saying something that is generally, but not completely, true
examples: By and large, I enjoyed my time at school.
Women generally earn less than men.
Generally speaking, jobs traditionally done by women are paid at a lower rate than those traditionally done by men.
In general, women do not earn as much as men.
By and large, women remain in the lower-paid jobs in the labour market
Certain jobs, like nursing and cleaning, are still mainly carried out by women.
Senior management posts are predominantly held by men.
Most senior management posts tend to be held by men.
Women are, for the most part, still paid less than men.
Economic and social factors are, to a large extent, responsible for women being concentrated in low-paid jobs.

senses.definition: used for showing how or in what way something is done
examples: The house is heated by gas.
May I pay by credit card?
I will contact you by letter.
to travel by boat/bus/car/plane
to travel by air/land/sea
Switch it on by pressing this button.

senses.definition: near somebody/something; at the side of somebody/something; next to somebody/something
examples: a house by the river
Can we have the table by the window?
Come and sit by me.

senses.definition: used, usually after a passive verb, to show who or what does, creates or causes something
examples: He was knocked down by a bus.
a play by Ibsen
Who's that book by?
I was frightened by the noise.
Some people buy all their groceries online.
I think he was motivated by his mother.
Don't let the opportunity pass you by.
Bye! See you later.

senses.definition: not later than the time mentioned; before
examples: Can you finish the work by five o'clock?
I'll have it done by tomorrow.
By this time next week we'll be in New York.
He ought to have arrived by now/by this time.
By the time (that) this letter reaches you I will have left the country.

senses.definition: used before particular nouns without the, to say that something happens as a result of something
examples: They met by chance.
I did it by mistake.
The coroner's verdict was ‘death by misadventure’.

senses.definition: used to show the degree or amount of something
examples: The bullet missed him by two inches.
House prices went up by 10%.
It would be better by far (= much better) to…

senses.definition: during something; in a particular situation
examples: to travel by day/night
We had to work by candlelight.

senses.definition: from what something shows or says; according to something
examples: By my watch it is two o'clock.
I could tell by the look on her face that something terrible had happened.
By law, you are a child until you are 18.

senses.definition: past somebody/something
examples: He walked by me without speaking.

senses.definition: used to show the part of somebody/something that somebody touches, holds, etc.
examples: I took him by the hand.
She seized her by the hair.
Pick it up by the handle!

senses.definition: used with the to show the period or quantity used for buying, selling or measuring something
examples: We rented the car by the day.
They're paid by the hour.
We only sell it by the metre.

senses.definition: used to state the rate at which something happens
examples: They're improving day by day.
We'll do it bit by bit.
It was getting worse by the minute (= very fast).
The children came in two by two (= in groups of two).

senses.definition: used to show the measurements of something
examples: The room measures fifteen feet by twenty feet.

senses.definition: used when multiplying or dividing
examples: 6 multiplied by 2 equals 12.
6 divided by 2 equals 3.

senses.definition: used for giving more information about where somebody comes from, what somebody does, etc.
examples: He's German by birth.
They're both doctors by profession.

senses.definition: used when swearing to mean ‘in the name of’
examples: I swear by Almighty God…

senses.definition: used to introduce a comment or question that is not directly related to what you have been talking about
goodbye
examples: Bye! See you next week.
She waved bye-bye and got into the car.
Bye for now Dad!
